item.title: Maybe we should stop using ‚ÄúWhite supremacist‚Äù and ‚Äúbad‚Äù interchangeably?
item.description:
Recently, I‚Äôve been noticing this weird trend. It‚Äôs become prevalent within the social justice movement, and I haven‚Äôt seen anyone else flag it. I brought it up in the context of our Social Justice, Minus Dogma Course + Community, and it turns out other people are noticing it too. So let‚Äôs flag it.

The short version is this:

A lot of people are using domination/oppression language (e.g., ‚Äúwhite supremacist‚Äù, ‚Äúpatriarchal‚Äù) as synonyms for ‚Äúbad‚Äù and marginalization/anti-oppression language (e.g., ‚Äúindigenous,‚Äù ‚Äúdecolonized,‚Äù ‚Äúfeminist‚Äù) as synonyms for ‚Äúgood‚Äù ‚Äî devoid of any meaningful connection to the actual structure, system, or culture they‚Äôre mentioning.

My guess is that it‚Äôs a combination of our over focusing on ‚Äú-ists‚Äù instead of ‚Äú-isms‚Äù plus the ‚Äúsocial justice power inverse,‚Äù but I‚Äôll leave the detective work up to you.

Why highlight this at all? In short, because actual, sincere, real-life White supremacy is on the rise, and we need to be able to call it when we see it.

Calling things ‚ÄúWhite supremacist‚Äù that aren‚Äôt creates a lot of unhelpful noise.

I wrote this article a few days before we got a blazingly clear example of White supremacy in action, when U.S. President Donald Trump went on a ‚Äúgo back to your country‚Äù rant against several members of congress, all of whom are women of color.

Being careful to use the phrase ‚ÄúWhite supremacy‚Äù correctly would allow a criticism of Trump‚Äôs rant, and other White supremacist actions, to be held as distinct from general criticisms of Trump.

Both are totally valid, by the way! However, we need to know which basket we‚Äôre putting our eggs into.

We need to be able to separate ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like what you‚Äôre saying‚Äù from ‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôre saying is advancing White supremacy and ethnic cleansing.‚Äù

And right now we‚Äôre not doing a good job of that, at all.

I‚Äôll explain what I‚Äôm talking about in more detail, then talk about a few of the reasons I think this is (deeply) unhelpful.

I‚Äôd be curious to hear what you think, if you‚Äôre also noticing this. We‚Äôll make space for that, too.

‚ÄúWhite Supremacist‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean a ‚ÄúWhite person doing something bad‚Äù

Let me first say that, overall, it‚Äôs great that more people are becoming comfy using phrases like ‚Äúwhite supremacist.‚Äù

The same goes for words like ‚Äúpatriarchal,‚Äù ‚Äúcolonial,‚Äù ‚Äúheterosexist,‚Äù etc. They‚Äôre useful words that can be used to pinpoint exactly what we‚Äôre talking about, concerned about in society, and wanting to change.

(If we could just add ‚Äúcapitalist‚Äù to our comfort zone, we might even make bell hooks proud.)

The issue I‚Äôm flagging here is not the use of the phrase ‚Äúwhite supremacist‚Äù (or any of these other words I‚Äôm lumping together as domination/oppression language).

The issue is people using these words like duct tape, sticking them to every problem they notice.

Here‚Äôs what it looks like in general:

item.title: How much injustice can we justify on the path toward social justice?
item.description:
Close your eyes and imagine the world you would describe as living social justice. Equitable. Utopian, even. Whatever comes to mind.

Give it a shot. I‚Äôll wait a moment.

What does it feel like to occupy that [future world][1] where all of our work as [social justice people][2] came to fruition?

How does it differ from our world today?

How radical of a difference you notice will be determined by the world you have in your mind. But surely the ways we spend our time, the social problems we grapple with, and even the ways we organize societies aren‚Äôt the same.

What do ‚Äújobs‚Äù look like? Do they even still exist? What about politics? What will there be more of? What will there be less of?

There‚Äôs likely a long list of [actions, attitudes, and beliefs][3] that wouldn‚Äôt make sense in that world, but seem perfectly sensical in our world right now.

What comes to mind?

Focus on the gap, the distance between what would be normal in a socially-just world, compared to what is normal now in our oppressive and unjust world.

Okay, now here comes the really tough part:

item.title: -isms, not -ists
item.description:
To achieve the goals of social justice, we need to reform society at the system level. We need to dismantle rac_ism_, sex_ism_, cissex_ism_, heterosex_ism_, gender_ism_, able_ism_, class_ism_, and more.

Too much of social justice discourse and calls-to-action are focused on the -ists, the people participating in (and perpetuating) those systems.

Our focus on individual actors keeps increasing in social justice spaces I occupy. It‚Äôs almost all of what I notice in online social justice activism/advocacy. I‚Äôm guessing you‚Äôve noticed it, too.

This focus often takes the form of punitive social justice, identifying perpetrators, dragging them, publicly shaming them, ‚Äúcanceling‚Äù them.

item.title: The Privilege Lie
item.description:
I‚Äôve said it myself. I‚Äôve read it a hundred times. You‚Äôve probably heard it, or said it yourself. It usually goes something like, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not asking you to give up your privileges. We‚Äôre trying to grant access to others who don‚Äôt have them.‚Äù

Or a pie analogy: ‚ÄúPrivilege isn‚Äôt like pie. You don‚Äôt have to give up your slice for others to enjoy it.‚Äù

The idea behind these sentiments is that the goal of social justice is not to take privileges away from the ‚Äúprivileged‚Äù and give them to the ‚Äúoppressed‚Äù (an unhelpful binary).

When we list privileges (e.g., male privileges, cisgender privileges, Christian privileges) and ask people to ‚Äúcheck their privilege,‚Äù we say we‚Äôre not asking them to give anything up.

Instead, we say that the goal is for everyone to have access to those privileges.

We say this, usually, as a defense to [privileged] people pushing back against our goals.

And it‚Äôs a lie. A well-intentioned lie, but a lie nonetheless.

item.title: Replacing One Binary with Another
item.description:
I‚Äôve always believed that one of our superpowers as gender/sexuality activists, and social justice people more broadly, is our ability to hold space for nuance. In the past few years, that belief has been crumbling. In part because of how much I‚Äôm seeing us replace one way of binary thinking for another.

For a long time, we‚Äôve known that sexuality isn‚Äôt a binary thing. It‚Äôs not gay/straight, either/or. It‚Äôs often both/and, neither, or another option altogether. The Kinsey Scale often comes to mind here.

More recently, we‚Äôve recognized the same thing about gender. We‚Äôve addressed the complexities of gender, viewing it on a spectrum, or, better, on scales. And broken through the binary of woman/man. Just like sexuality, it‚Äôs not an either/or, but more of a both/and, neither, or another option altogether.

Now, it‚Äôs not entirely clear to me that everyone writing about binaries (e.g., the gender binary) is saying the same thing.

So allow me to be clear what I mean (and have always meant) by binary: two options. Two ways to be. Two categories. And that‚Äôs it. Only two.

item.title: The Social Justice Power Inverse
item.description:
A lot of social justice conversations focus on power. Who has power in society and who doesn‚Äôt?

We highlight how systems inequitably distribute power to some while withholding it from others ‚Äî based on who we are.

We refer to people who are granted disproportionate power as ‚Äúprivileged,‚Äù ‚Äúmajoritized,‚Äù ‚Äúcentered,‚Äù etc. And those from whom power is withheld as ‚Äúoppressed,‚Äù ‚Äúminoritized,‚Äù ‚Äúmarginalized,‚Äù etc.

Now, nobody is only one of those two. We‚Äôre both, depending on which situation we‚Äôre in, and what dimensions of ourselves are brought to the forefront.

Our goal in talking about this is dismantling inequitable power structures.

The needle on our compass points toward equity. Removing barriers, promoting access, and shrinking the gap between the ‚Äúhaves‚Äù and ‚Äúhave nots‚Äù ‚Äî or, in a perfect world, making that dichotomy irrelevant.

One of the things we don‚Äôt talk about is how power structures manifest in social justice spaces, or the micro-society that is the community of social justice people.

Here, we preserve the idea of the power structure, but swap out who sits where.

item.title: The Two Worlds Dilemma
item.description:
Every justice movement ‚Äî from gender, to sexuality, to every other dimension of who we are and how the world sees us ‚Äî has to answer two big questions: What‚Äôs wrong with the world now? And what future world do you want to create?

I‚Äôm the fly on the wall for thousands of conversations about social justice. And a lot of what I witness online and in-person (in workshops and conferences and retreats) goes off the rails because of The Two Worlds Dilemma.

item.title: How (Not) To Use a Privilege List
item.description:
The Privilege Lists that I‚Äôve published here have been downloaded over 100 million times cumulatively. I share this because it‚Äôs cool to say (big number!), but also because that reach has allowed me to see these lists used in a variety of ways: some good, some neutral, and some downright harmful.

The ways to use a privilege list are innumerable, and the creativity I‚Äôve witnessed has been astounding. As a tool, they can be transformative.

So instead of using this space to advocate for ways I encourage using the lists, it‚Äôll be easier to write few quick ‚ÄúPlease Don‚Äôt Do This‚Äù bullets:

item.title: Introducing the Social Justice Compass
item.description:
Are you sailing the seas of social injustice, looking for a path toward equity, and in need of a tool that can point you in the right direction? Perhaps you are rethinking how you do social justice now, today, in 2019 ‚Äî with everything happening in the world ‚Äî and searching for a new path forward.

Avast! A new model for thinking about and doing social justice‚Ä¶ ho! This is off to a bad start. It turns out that every day can be International Talk like a Pirate Day if you don‚Äôt care about having friends.

But if you care about social justice, friend, well, look no further!

Today, I‚Äôm happy to share with you a new model for thinking about social justice, for considering your actions, attitudes, and beliefs, and for guiding yourself and your community toward equity: The Social Justice Compass.

Let‚Äôs dive right in.

item.title: If You‚Äôre Still Doing Social Justice How You Were Then, Reconsider.
item.description:
I‚Äôve seen people at conferences giving the same talk they gave two years ago. Activists speaking and organizing in ways unchanged since 2015. Educators facilitating workshops with a curriculum written in 2012.

The world is different now than it was then.

The people you‚Äôre working with ‚Äî or against, or for ‚Äî have different mindsets, beliefs, knowledge, perspectives, values, opinions, grudges, predispositions, awarenesses, and biases now than they did then.

The world you‚Äôre working in ‚Äî and trying to improve ‚Äî is comprised of different technologies, constituencies, zeitgeists, cultural norms, and public knowledge now than it was then.

And the ‚Äúthen‚Äù could be yesterday. Or last year. Your ‚Äúthen‚Äù could be ‚Äúbefore Trump was elected. Or ‚Äúwhen we didn‚Äôt know this huge thing.‚Äù Or ‚Äúbefore ‚ÄòBlack Lives Matter‚Äô activism started.‚Äù Or ‚Äúwhen we weren‚Äôt sure whether this one thing would work or not.‚Äù Or ‚Äúbefore our community experienced that travesty.‚Äù Or ‚Äúwhen we didn‚Äôt have social media.‚Äù

When I started doing social justice work, most people didn‚Äôt know what ‚Äúsocial justice‚Äù meant. They‚Äôd never heard the phrase. It was brand new to them. That was the first bar to jump: explaining what I was working to do.

That‚Äôs a ‚Äúthen‚Äù: when most people I encountered hadn‚Äôt heard the phrase ‚Äúsocial justice.‚Äù

item.title: What Hypocrisy Theatre Is, and Why It Doesn‚Äôt Work
item.description:
Let‚Äôs say a friend of yours made a New Year‚Äôs resolution to stop being on their phone during dinner. It‚Äôs January 4th, you‚Äôre sharing a table, and you catch them peeping their insta. You call them on it, they apologize, and put their phone away.

Hypocrisy, meet behavior. Behavior, meet change. Huzzah!

That‚Äôs how calling someone out on their hypocrisy works. There are a few important factors here:

  1. The person you‚Äôre calling out has stated (or otherwise believes) that they want to walk a particular (moral) path: ‚ÄúFrom¬†now¬†on,¬†I‚Äôm¬†going¬†to¬†do X.‚Äù
  2. You notice their actions are contrary to that, and actively getting in the way of them living that espoused value, or walking their talk.
  3. You point out this gap: ‚ÄúYou said you were going to do X, but now you‚Äôre doing Anti-X.‚Äù
  4. This prompts cognitive dissonance, and they have to pick a path: do as they said they‚Äôd do, or give up on that moral stance.

Each one of those four steps is necessary. They work as a chain reaction.

Welcome to Hypocrisy Theatre: Where Social Media is Our Stage and Our Audience is Only People Who Already Agree With Us

For several years now, there‚Äôs been a new show in town: Hypocrisy Theatre. And unlike the example above, Hypocrisy Theatre isn‚Äôt effective in changing the hypocrite‚Äôs behavior. Indeed, they‚Äôre not even part of the audience.

Maybe you‚Äôve caught a performance of it?

The cast changes daily, but the show always follows the same script: some random person on social media points out that some other random person they disagree with once said something that flies in the face of a thing they‚Äôre saying now.

It often looks like this:

item.title: The Elephant in Every Socially-Just Room
item.description:
For the past year, I‚Äôve been in conversation with folks about what I‚Äôve been calling the ‚ÄúSocial Justice Dogma.‚Äù I‚Äôve written about it here¬†(read all), tried to interview people about it for a podcast, and I‚Äôve been having lots and lots of phone calls with social justice educators.

In literally every case, when I‚Äôd start a conversation about Social Justice Dogma (SJD), the person I was talking with recognized the phenomenon, without me needing to explain what I meant ‚Äî¬†¬†even if they‚Äôd never heard the phrase ‚Äúsocial justice dogma.‚Äù

They‚Äôd reply with something like, ‚ÄúOh, I know what you‚Äôre talking about,‚Äù or ‚ÄúOh yeah, that‚Äôs a big thing in my circle.‚Äù

Then we‚Äôd get into some particular tenet that they were struggling with. Or talk through a recent current event, using the dogma as the lens.

And the conversations generally ended the same, with them saying something like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy you‚Äôre talking about this‚Äù or ‚ÄúThis conversation is needed‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to seeing more on this.‚Äù

But then the conversation ended.

item.title: What kind of ‚ÄúSocial Justice‚Äù are you talking about?
item.description:
I had lunch with a friend this week, and our conversation hit a peculiar roadblock: A lot of people are saying the same words ‚Äî ‚Äúsocial justice‚Äù ‚Äî but meaning different things. This is a problem.

When you say ‚Äúsocial justice,‚Äù what kind of justice are you talking about?

item.title: 3 Tenets of Social Justice Dogma that are Getting in Our Way
item.description: Now that I‚Äôve been talking openly about Social Justice Dogma (SJD) for a few months, I have some findings I want to share. Below I‚Äôve written about a bunch of tenets of the SJD that are likely unhelpful, counter-productive, or downright obstructive to the goals of social justice.

item.title: Social Justice Fandom (AKA Creating New Barriers in the Name of Dismantling Others)
item.description: Maybe it was Glee. I don‚Äôt know. But at some point, within a small subsection of a small subsection of the population, social justice became cool. And whenever something becomes cool, two things tend to follow. The first is that some of the people who like the cool thing start to covet it, protect it from outsiders, and claim it as their own ‚Äî when just moments before those same people were making desperate pleas to others to like the thing they liked.

item.title: The Magical Power of ‚ÄúSome‚Äù for Social Justice Educators
item.description: There are few things that changed how effective of a social justice educator I was as much as the word ‚Äúsome.‚Äù It started as a way to correct people, or redirect them, or respond to problematic questions. Someone would ask something like ‚ÄúWhen people say they‚Äôre bisexual, isn‚Äôt it really just a phase?

item.title: Some Different Taxonomies for Social Justice People
item.description: We often group social justice people by identity, cause, or ‚Äú-ism‚Äù (e.g., racial justice people, gender justice, queer justice, wage justice). People outside of the social justice movement seem inclined to group SJ people as being either ‚Äúsocial justice warriors‚Äù or not.

item.title: One Huge Prickly Reason Why Anti-LGBTQ Folks Don‚Äôt Change Their Views
item.description: I need you to take a leap with me. Leap into the shoes of someone who has walked through their life knowing that being gay, being bi, lesbian, or pan, or that being non-binary, gender non-conforming, or trans ‚Äî that being different, different from straight, different from cisgender ‚Äî is wrong.

item.title: Why I Finally Broke My Silence about the Social Justice Dogma
item.description: A few days ago I wrote what I described as the scariest thing I‚Äôve ever published to this site. So why did I do it? Why take the risk? That‚Äôs what I want to write about today. Now, I know ‚Äúscariest‚Äù is a relative term.

item.title: I can‚Äôt stop thinking about the ‚ÄúSocial Justice Dogma,‚Äù or keeping quiet.
item.description: Last spring, I got to spend a couple weeks in rural Ontario giving a few dozen (!) talks, assemblies, and shows at schools and organizations around the province. Every time I visit the Ontario countryside, I‚Äôm struck by how much it reminds me of my now-home state of Texas, in ways that are equal parts comfy (lots of hospitality) and uncomfy (lots of camouflage and usage of the word ‚Äúlifestyle‚Äù).

item.title: Every Shirt is Political.
Taking Up Space vs. Adding to a Space: Questions to Consider
item.description: A lot of us want to just ‚Äúbe people,‚Äù and leave our social identities at the door when we enter a room. In September 2016, I was asked to participate in Katie Couric‚Äôs ‚ÄúGender Revolution‚Äù documentary (by National Geographic). The following questions were what I worked through ‚Äî and what I generally work through ‚Äî when deciding to say ‚Äúyes‚Äù or ‚Äúno.

item.description: I‚Äôve organized and participated in a lot of political¬†resistance over the years. From high school walkouts, to college sit-ins, to guerrilla activism campaigns, to marches and public demonstrations. item.description: “Meg and Sam have given us a gift; their book is smartly designed to invite new and seasoned facilitators to be intentional about having those tough group discussions. As an educator and facilitator, this book gives me a framework to understand my own facilitation style, and ways that I can continue to improve.

item.title: Empathy leads to Understanding
item.description: The other day I was at Lehigh University engaging in a bunch of conversations about identity, sexuality, gender, and social justice (ya know ‚Äî my jam). The groups I was talking with and to were eager and willing to learn, which is not to be taken for granted, but a sentiment kept popping up:¬†‚ÄúThis identity stuff is complicated.

item.title: Dear White, Straight, Cisgender, Man People: You Are Privileged
item.description: I‚Äôve written about privilege here, and I‚Äôve written my own privilege lists, inspired by Peggy McIntosh (blame her!), which have garnered a lot of hullabaloo on my site. Now, there seems to be a groundswell of backlash, where privileged people (like this super privileged Princeton student) are ‚Äúdenouncing their privilege‚Äù and ‚Äúfinally standing up for straight white guys‚Äù (HAHAHA).

item.title: I Have Not Given You Consent
item.description: I work on the internet. It‚Äôs true. I write things for you to read (or not read), and spend a lot of my free time creating things that may (or may not) help you fill yours. I‚Äôm not asking for thanks, or really asking for you to do anything at all, but there are a few things I‚Äôm asking that you don‚Äôt do.

item.description: It‚Äôs no secret I‚Äôm not a big fan of how highly we regard intentions. There‚Äôs even a whole chapter in my bookabout it, and it recently led to a great conversation, which led to this more visual representation of the dynamics between intentions and outcomes.

item.title: 15+ Fantastic Resources for Talking about ‚ÄúHomosexuality‚Äù (i.e., LGBTQ people) and The Bible
item.description: Only a tiny, tiny part of the bible can even be argued to reference ‚Äúhomosexuality‚Äù (and that argument, in a few of the verses in particular, is worth looking into), yet it seems like whenever we hear about the Bible in the news it‚Äôs being slammed against LGBTQ equality.

item.title: Being an Ally Between a Rock and a Hard Place
item.description: I‚Äôm an ally. I‚Äôve written before why I‚Äôm an ally, and I‚Äôve even once defended my allyship publicly, highlighting many of my privileged identities. But one thing I‚Äôve never fully addressed is the double-edged-sword, Kobayashi-Maru-no-win scenario that¬†_can be¬†_what it means to be an ally like me.

item.title: 50+ concrete things you can do today to make for a more socially just tomorrow
item.description:
Social justice ‚Äî the idea that everyone in a society, regardless of the identities they embody, can have an equitable shot at success and happiness ‚Äî is a goal that seems unrealistic for many people. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pipe dream, Sam,‚Äù they say, smugly. ‚ÄúLife isn‚Äôt rainbows and butterflies,‚Äù they say, adorably.

üíåMost Wednesdays

To achieve social justice we will have to break down a lot of huge barriers that exist on a scale far above the individual, but even the biggest scale change is nothing more than the sum of a whole lot of individual efforts. ¬†My goal with this site is to support you in doing just that: making big change on an individual level.

Following are a whole¬†lot of individual efforts you can make today that will be significant steps toward that biggest scale change we need for a socially just tomorrow.

item.title: 30+ Examples of Middle-to-Upper Class Privileges
item.description: Following is a list of middle-to-upper class privileges. If you are a member of the middle class or upper class economic groups (or, in some cases, perceived to be) listed below are benefits that may be granted to you based on your group membership ‚Äî benefits not granted to folks in the lower classes.

item.title: You Soup: understanding diversity and the intersections of identity
item.description:
In doing the work I do, I often find myself struggling to help people make sense of the two extremes of identity: on one side we have the idea that people in a group are all the same (stereotypes); while the other side supports this idea that everyone is absolutely unique (snowflakes).

I find myself saying ‚Äúwe‚Äôre not the same, but we‚Äôre also not that different,‚Äù to the furrowing of brows, so I wanted to take a moment here to talk about the relationship of individual identity and social group memberships, as well as introduce a new graphic concept.

item.title: Build Your Own World
item.description:
Look around you. ¬†Every product, gadget, building, company ‚Äî every thing ‚Äî was created by a person who is just like you or me or Uncle Jesse from Full House (kidding ‚Äî nobody is like Uncle Jesse). ¬†

As you walk through your life, you‚Äôre surrounded by the accomplishments and influences of individuals of the past and present. ¬†You‚Äôre surrounded by a world they built ‚Äî for you, and everyone around you.

I, for one, am not entirely happy with the world that has been built for me. ¬†I want to live in a world that is socially just, where individuals all have the same access to the good stuff ‚Äî education, jobs, swedish fish, etc. ‚Äî regardless of the identities they do or do not possess. ¬†If you‚Äôre like me, you‚Äôve likely thought, at some point, something along the lines of¬†I want to make this world a better place to live in.

item.title: How To Avoid Being a Stereotype
item.description:
You want to be seen as an individual, right? ¬†Of course you do. ¬†But it‚Äôs bordering on impossible to avoid perpetuating at least some of the stereotypes attached to the various aspects of your identity. ¬†There are just too many of them!

Well, that‚Äôs where I can help. ¬†Consider this a ‚ÄúHow to be [X], without being a stereotypical [X]‚Äù guide. ¬†I‚Äôm hitting a variety of major identities, but feel free to request addendums to the guide in the comments below, on Facebook, or on Twitter.

Also, if you‚Äôre more prone to spot-reading than reading-reading, I strongly encourage you to at least read the last section before you formulate your reaction to this article.

Without further ado, in alphabetical order‚Ä¶
